title: How did you think of the plot for your novel? - Quora

response.answer_text: It's been said that every story has already been told. This is true. It's just how YOU tell it.  Boy meets girl. Boy loses girl. Boy gets girl back. Basic love story. Cliched? Sure. But not when you put your voice on it, throw in a subplot of some kind, a few twists -- and voila. A 'new' story.  It is said there are 7 basic plots that are used again and again. The Quest Voyage and Return Comedy Tragedy Rebirth Overcoming the Monster Rags to Riches Ronald B. Tobias, author of 20 Master Plots. Cincinnati: Writer’sDigest Books, 1993. (ISBN 0-89879-595-8) proposes twenty basic plots: QuestAdventurePursuitRescueEscapeRevengeThe  RiddleRivalryUnderdog TemptationMetamorphosis Transformation Maturation Love  Forbidden Love  Sacrifice DiscoveryWretched Excess AscensionDecensionChose which plot you want to work with.  Let's say youlike 'escape'.  It could be a jail escape, escape from a bad relationship,or someone lost in a jungle.  Your imagination is limitless.  Hone inon the one that intrigues you most.  Let's say you want to write a storyabout an escape from a bad marriage.  Now figure out your characters,pinpoint the WHY the person wants to escape (someone is cheating, gambling,lying, is abusive), and start plotting your story from there.  Be sure tonot write a predictable story, throw in a few twists.  Let's say the wifewas leaving her husband because she finds out he has a new girlfriend at work,so she goes to the bank to draw out their savings and finds out the money hasalready been taken out.  Now how does she leave with no money? Where's alltheir money? Now she has to go back home and pretend everything is fine untilshe finds out what's going on.  Or she goes to get in her car, she's got her suitcase in hand, and the car is not in the driveway.  It's been stolen or repossessed.  Or have her male coworker start to flirt with her.  Have her husband see her doing something with this man a wife shouldn't be doing, like giving the new guy a kiss goodbye or a hug.  Now the husband confronts the wife for cheating, when he's the bigger cheat.  Give her lots of problems to make the story more interesting. Only you can write it and twist it in such a way that your voice comes through and it makes the story fresh, turns and old plot into something new.

Now this is a question I’d love to answer not only for you, but also for myself. I’ve been creating my fictional world and planning out my novel passively since around 2011 and actively since 2014/15. I have never been much of a bookworm, I always ended up being uninterested or unsatisfied by what most people of my age read. When I started taking notes, I was convinced that my novel could be created without inspiration, and I was determined to do so. I created so many things from scratch, not just continents, history and a language, but also physics, teology, biology. However, as time passed, more and more things that I wanted to use but were already used in another stories rose up. My elder brother, who started studying literature analytics at the University of Kent in 2015 convinced me that I couldn’t write a story without inspiration. So I inspired myself. Very vaguely. By video games. I always had a talent for finding meaning in things without meaning. I often looked up what a fantasy videogame is about, just the main plot, not the detailed lore/storyline, and I made up everything else. That’s right, I inspired myself by my own… fanfiction, I guess? Or rather by my expectations of the video game story? Anyway, the story I made up in my mind was usually way better than the real one, obviously… *cough* Anyway, there are a few straightforward similarities, but it’s usually just little things. My battle scenes are inspired by my swordfighting experiences and tournaments. So, finally, realistic sword fights in a book! What a wonderful age to live in. The main plot of my novel came out of the mist just last year. Originally, the novel (initially meant to consist of 21 volumes!) was just a bunch of correlated storylines of characters that I related with during different parts of my teenage years. Every 6–12 months, I thought of a new character which fitted my new ideals better. But I didn’t erase the old characters. That way, the story got more and more complex, but it lacked a backbone. Something which it all orbits around. Sure, there was a historical storyline, I knew what would happen, how it would happen, but I didn’t know why it would happen. So I added a giant plot twist. I’m not sure if I should tell you. It’s something which turns all the little stories of the little characters into one giant, meaningful, hard-to-process lump of mind-blowingness. Or at least I hope it’s like that… *cough* I compressed it into one book consisting of three volumes called (in English): Litevale, Belevalia and Folfjord, the names of regions where the story takes place. When I told my brother how I write it, I mean the style of my writing, he was pretty happy, and frankly, he’s not easy to satisfy. It’s original. It’s different. It could be interesting to read. It’s not chronological, it’s not retrospective, it’s not episodic, it’s a mix of everything. It’s not a novel nor a saga, it’s both. I don’t narrate in typical third-person, I use the “Eye of the Camera” storytelling, but personalized, significantly different. It’s not realistic fantasy, it’s not high fantasy, I actually don’t think it’s fantasy at all. I don’t know what it is, but I love it. I hated my novel for years. I thought I could do better, that it lacked something, that it’s written terribly. And now, after thousands of hours of hard work, I can finally say: “I love my novel. I believe it’ll be perfect.”  EDIT: “SO WHAT THE HELL IS THIS NOVEL?!” It’s a story describing lifes of distant relatives living in different parts of a continent named Gezes, or Timeworld in Gisoinic (the ground language). Every 3–25 pages, the point of view changes, but usually in an unchronological manner, meaning the reader constantly jumps back and forth in time. The main plot of Litevale orbits around the Feluminic invasion, appearance of an unknown race from the East and around the Grand Tournament of Belevalia (swordfights!). The main plot of Belevalia orbits around an event called “The Purge of Nations” and the main plot of Folfjord orbits around the “Fall of Veashe”. I’m not gonna explain those, it would spoil the story. It’s all a symbolism of the constant fight between ignorance and knowledge, so no, there’s no good vs evil. As I mentioned above, most of the story is inspired by my teenage experiences, and done so in an extremely symbolistic, epicized and brutalized manner. It also theorizes about the true definition of a soul, afterlife and the ultimate truth about the universe, dimensions, infinity and stuff like that. So… something for everyone, I guess?
